name: sheep production, for meat | sheep for slaughtering, live weight | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/4366/documentation

This unit process represents average sheep production for meat with the outputs of 62.8 kg of sheep for slaughtering, live weight and a by-product of 4.2 kg of sheep fleece in the grease (average output of husbandry of one sheep during one year). This dataset is a copy dataset from the respective US geography and therefore might not represent fully the global situation.;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.];[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:]

This activity represents the expenditures and emissions of the husbandry of 1 sheep during 1 year. It includes the processes and inputs of sheep husbandry on pasture land (20% intensive and 80% extensive pasture land). Inputs of fertilisers, feedstuffs, pesticides and irrigation are considered. 


Machine infrastructure and a shed for machine sheltering and shearing is included. The direct emissions on the field are also included. The system boundary is at the farm gate. The products of sheep husbandry are wool and sheep live weight. All further processes after the farm gate like transport to the slaughterhouse, slaughtering, cooling, etc. are excluded.
The output of sheepskin (3 kg per sheep per year) is not recorded as a by-product.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/014:Animal production/0144:Raising of sheep and goats

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The yield data have been collected for the years 2001-2006.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Refers to an average production in the USA
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Conventional production typical for the country. Water for irrigation is pumped from 48 meter depth by electric pumps.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data come from the NREL database and from varoius U.S database. Data were compiled from statistics, literature, farm survey reports, documents from extension services, and expert knowledge.

exchanges.description:
Average weight of a alive sheep for slaughtering. --- Source: NASS - National Agricultural Statistics Service 2007, retrieved 2 Feb 2007 from http://www.nass.usda.gov.
EcoSpold01Location=US

flow.name: sheep for slaughtering, live weight
flow.category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/014:Animal production/0144:Raising of sheep and goats

exchanges.description:
Value from Nemecek et al. (2004) represents intensive pastures. According to Wells et. al (2000) 80% of sheep pastures are extensive (with reduced or no cultivation). Value from Nemecek et al. (2004) is multiplied by 0.2 in order to account for the share of extensive pastures and divided by stocking density (12.4 sheep per hectare according to AVNA 2007). --- Sources: Wells A., Gegner L.E. & Earles R. 2000. Sustainable Sheep Production - Livestock Production Guide, Appropriate Technology Transfer for Rural Areas (ATTRA), retrieved 6.6.2007 from http://www.attra.ncat.org/attra-pub/PDF/sheep.pdf ---- AVNA - American Veterinary Naturopathic Association (2007) Forage Needs for Meat Goats and Sheep. Retrieved on 25 June 2007 from http://avna.us/14.htm.
EcoSpold01Location=CH

exchanges.description: Emissions from enteric fermentation and manure according to Taipale (2006). Emissions from fertilisers according to Goolsby (1999). --- Sources: Taipale C., 2006 Colorado 2002 Ammonia Emission Inventory. Colorado Department of Public Health & Environment. --- Goolsby D.A., Battaglin W.A., Lawrence G.B.,  Artz R.S., Aulenbach B.T., Hooper R.P., Keeney D.R. & Stensland G.J. (1999) Flux and Sources of Nutrients in the Mississippi-Atchafalaya River Basin - Topic 3 Report for the integrated Assessment on Hypoxia in the Gulf of Mexico. Decision Analysis Series No. 17, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, U.S. Department of Commerce, p. 159.

flow.name: Ammonia
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Calculated value. See the parameters and their comments to understand the calculation.

Calculated after Goolsby et al. (1999): emission factor of 61% of the N-input (fertilisers and N fixation). Originally  estimated for the nitrate leaching in the Mississipi region.  Extrapolated to the whole USA.

The exchange has been updated from 'ammonium nitrate, as N' into 'ammonium nitrate' and therefore its amount has been scaled (multiplied) from 1.37 kg by 2.8573 kg of 'ammonium nitrate' per kg of 'ammonium nitrate, as N'. Original comment of the exchange is: Value from NREL (2006) assumes only intensive pastures. According to Wells et. al (2000) 80% of sheep pastures are extensive (with reduced or no cultivation). Value from NREL (2006) is multiplied by 0.2 in order to account for the share of extensive pastures. --- Source: Wells A., Gegner L.E. & Earles R. 2000. Sustainable Sheep Production - Livestock Production Guide, Appropriate Technology Transfer for Rural Areas (ATTRA), retrieved 6.6.2007 from http://www.attra.ncat.org/attra-pub/PDF/sheep.pdf
